the afternoon please go ahead Thanks yeah thanks AWS and Elizabeth for
giving me this opportunity so my name is Pia nandan I am the CEO of this young
new not-for-profit Research Institute looking at how a I can help solve
problems in society we knew AI for social good so we are a independent
not-for-profit thanks to the generosity of two entrepreneurial you know X
Indians living in the u.s. now who giving back to society so we have benefits of their philanthropy they had
this idea a couple of years ago so Neil Wadhwani and Ramesh Wadhwani to create an institute that will develop AI
solutions with the idea of addressing underserved communities throughout the world I mean to set the context if you
look at you know where AI is today it's everywhere I mean you probably used it
when you did right share or everyone of course thinks about self-driving cars robots ecommerce any number of things
but those things are useful for about maybe about 40% of the world maybe 50%
of the world but but about three billion people are more whose lives are not really touched by the kind of technology
that you and I always use and the kind of infrastructure and solutions were building and for most of them India is a
country with about 900 million such people Africa Latin America or any
number of places in the world there are basic basic you know needs of life a basic way of making a living which often
turns out the agriculture basic healthcare just primary health emergency issues maternal
and child health infectious diseases those are an origin things and you know
there's not really go back there's not really a lot that's helping them or
basic education infrastructure water clean water power etc and some degree of
credit and Financial Inclusion our Charter is to look at how a I can help
address the problems for this community and how we can go implement them to set the context to illustrate it a little
bit let me talk about some projects we're working on at the moment you know we are a small organization one year old
in February 18th last year we were inaugurated by the Prime Minister of India so we got very good start and
visibility and that also shows why this topic is very important I think India as
a country sees potentially taking a leadership role in developing and applying AI for social good in fact the
Indian strategy document which was published last year specifically talks about this as a national sort of mission
and so when we started we looked around and we identified a couple of problems in health and one in aggregate and one
Nitra culture that we can actually address right away and so that's where we are so for example in health TB there
are about 10 plus million people new TB cases every year worldwide and about 1.7
million deaths I don't know if this is known but TB actually kills more people than HIV and malaria combined so it's
one of the predominant diseases it's entirely curable but it's not cured and there is an aspiration in India to
eradicate TB by 2025 we know very difficult India alone accounts for about
4 million plus cases of TB and there's a vagueness here we know from public
doctors to which patients go about one and a half million cases clearly known
and these are because whenever you go to a public doctor it's a notifiable disease so it's notified so the
government and other data keepers know but there are expected at least the same number if not more people with TB who
are not tracked who are not known and they may go - quacks private doctors get not get treatment and of course TB
is highly contagious so a couple of big challenges in TB that we discovered is
actually caseload estimation burden where the cases are and how to deploy resources now we're talking about the
situation but there are not a lot of healthcare resources we are talking about 900 million people there are not
enough doctors to take care of them so it tends to be front line health workers of one sort or the other or caseworkers
and there are not enough caseworkers to go around you know identifying four million people and so how do we
prioritize where they should go so we are looking at this as a problem that we can use data science and AI to kind of
prioritize the work of caseload workers the other side of TB that's important is
the treatment although TB is a curable disease when we take TB drugs it's very you know difficult it's a very poisonous
toxic drug and hurts you in other ways so typically the period of you know cure
is about six months people don't take it after about six weeks before they because they start feeling better and
this leads to you know bacteria that become resistant to drugs and today multi-drug resistance MDR TB and
extremely drug-resistant TB xdr-tb are quite common and they're becoming more
can we actually there are systems to monitor when people are not failing to
take but can we actually anticipate a predict ahead where you are likely to find such people so as to start
intervention before it's too late so these are two problems I must say here we are also the AI partner for the
central TB division of India which is the nodal agency that takes care of TB cure for India at the moment we are
still you know waiting to get data now the second area where we found you know we could do something very interesting
is actually in broadly a priority area for you know primary health care and
frontline healthcare which is maternal and child health pregnancies are risky and they're very risky when you know in
poor communities for any number of reasons but both maternal health and child cell infant mortality is still
high although it's come down in the years and one of the crucial ways in which you can detect potential infant
mortality is the baby at birth if the baby is two and half kilograms or less it's considered
to be risky and if it's 1.8 kilogram as this less it's critical however you know
even after 20 years of sending health care workers to the field baby weighing is not actually done properly about 30
percent of low birth weight babies there are about 4 million low birth weight babies in India 30 percent of them are
not actually weighed they take a spring balance and they ever there's a protocol for doing it but for a variety of
reasons it's cumbersome also the spring balances are usually broken and you know
supply chain problems so they don't get done and often people make up numbers they put in 2.5 kg because they I ball
the baby and say okay the baby is okay but that's not really a good thing so we're actually developing a vision based
solution where you can have a frontline health worker carry a smartphone take a few pictures of the baby or a video and
from which you know using computer vision techniques we can create a virtual three-dimensional model of the
baby and once we have in the model which to scale we can actually start making measurements like head circumference
head to toe these are indicators of a premature or you know baby that's dangerous and once we have the volume
baby's density is almost constant it's almost water so we can actually measure the weight this is technology where we
have an initial algorithm done but we need to validate using field data
collection I will talk a little bit more about that the third problem that we are working on is actually integrated pest
management in cotton farming cotton turns out to be a very important cash crop it's an aspirational crop and India
is the biggest cotton grower in the world and our Institute is situated in Mumbai which is a state of Maharashtra
it's also the biggest cotton state in India yet as much as you know you put in
the effort there are many small hold farmers the farmers are one acre or less so they don't have a lot of access to technology and their knowledge is also
limited agriculture extension workers are there to go and give them guidance but pest infestation turns out to be
still big challenge last year about 40% of crops in some of the states in India
cotton crops were wiped out due to one pest called the American Bald warm and there are about six different pests that
play cotton that are released critical and if you can measure their infestation early then you can decide
how much pesticide to use and limit overuse of pesticide or use it at the right time and we are actually
developing a vision technology to count pest infestation the way this is done is that there are traps that are set in the
field that are already there because that's how they do it today but farmers are you know agriculture extension
workers are supposed to look at these traps and count the number of pests of course they don't you know all kinds of other things on the traps pests that are
not dangerous so actually to see them and count them it's not that easy or we are building machine you know mission
based solutions that are able to detect the pests and count them there are six major threatening pests out of which we
have at the moment able to recognize three we're about to finish four but hopefully by this sometime this fall we
can do some field trials on this our approach you know sort of backing out is really one in which you know developing
the AI technology alone is not enough because the AI technology might be fine but unless it's product diced and used
in the right way because what needs to be done is to give it to the frontline health workers or the agricultural
extension workers not the end-user usually somebody who's supporting the end user and their capacity to use the
technology needs to be taken into account ability to deploy the solutions or one good thing is that smart phones
are getting ubiquitous there are about half a billion smartphone in phones in India right now and it's expected to
become a billion very soon and there is a mandate that all frontline health workers for example have to carry a
smartphone so once we think about it as a solution you know with the proper usage but product is even just one part
because you know it has to be plugged into a solution with other services that may be needed reaction to whatever you
measure unless that is done it's not going to really matter what you build but more importantly all of these has to
be part of a systems approach for example in health worker health care workers there is a system of primary
health care centers and sub centers about 120 under than a hundred and fifty
thousand sub centers and 25,000 primary health centers that exists across India
and basically roughly one sub center for every four village and sub centers are ran by
auxiliary nurse midwives and there are frontline health workers called OSHA workers about a million of them we know
how to deploy it through this chain of care unless there is some such thing you know developing an AI solution is not in
itself going to help but you know how do we decide well we decide by first asking
is this a problem that's worth solving how do we know that we know that because we have partners in the social sector
and governments who can teach us about it does it have any a solution of course we as tech people can figure it out
doing the AI is that going to make a difference because sometimes you may be solving a problem but that's not really
the critical thing that's going to you know stop progress and will the solution be accepted by the other stakeholders
doctors anyone in the healthcare chain and of course can we do the AI does a data exist or do we have to go create in
almost all cases we find that we have to take undertake some data creation process and are there partners who can
co-create and you know help us deploy and pilot and scale and of course all the government programs typically Sony
government that's there that can scale so way we look at it is this you know flow of work is really starting to talk
to our partners in the social sector typically they tend to be governments and other NGOs and domain experts and
then identify some use cases find a way to create the data set I do a tech POC
and then of course you know develop the solution and pilot it when most of them we are sort of in the left hand solution
phase now and hopefully in a few months we'll be seeing some you know field experiments and pilots you know a key
part of this is that if you want to do this you know yeah I for social good you can't do it alone there is not really
enough of a market in terms of revenue and even if there is getting to the market is going to be very difficult
it's not a place where you put out a product and you know somebody is going to buy it you need to work with different organizations and agencies in
different parts of the world different parts of the country different parts of the state even and be able to take that
process so you have to kind of change your way you think about how to build a solution and deliver a lot of fist has
to happen through collaboration with third parties that are experts but are not technical experts so that's what we
are about and I mean we are also looking at turning this into a kind of AI hub so
that not only we do the problem but also other organizations which are interested working in these problems can leverage
what we learned one part of it is really creating a data platform and a data ecosystem amongst other things
